Summary: The proposal aims to develop a unified framework for addressing fairness, safety, and privacy in AI systems, arguing that these are interdependent and require joint optimization. The method includes contextual fairness metrics, safety-fairness trade-off analysis, and privacy-preserving joint learning. The experiment plan involves benchmarking, development, optimization, real-world deployment, and longitudinal assessment.
Strengths: Rigorous experiment plan with benchmarking, real-world deployment, and longitudinal assessment.
Collaboration with domain experts and sociologists.
Weaknesses: Feasibility concerns about the joint optimization framework.
Lack of detailed discussion on handling conflicting objectives.
Potential complexity in integrating all three components.
Ambition may outweigh practical execution details.
Questions: How will conflicting objectives between fairness, safety, and privacy be resolved?
What are the specific technical challenges in integrating all three components, and how will they be addressed?
How will the framework scale to different types of AI systems and domains?
What are the potential failure modes of the joint optimization approach?
Limitations: Complexity of integrating fairness, safety, and privacy may lead to suboptimal solutions.
Potential trade-offs between objectives may not be fully resolvable.
Real-world deployment may reveal unforeseen challenges not accounted for in the proposal.
